bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Maguire, March 14, 1950

div1.p: Hench informs Maguire that this is the 50th anniversary of the conquest of yellow fever by Reed and his colleagues. He hopes that a suitable article might be prepared for some magazine. Since he does not have time to write an article, he inquires whether Maguire would be interested in taking up the task.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Maguire, March 14, 1950
div1.opener:
March 14, 1950
Mr. John Maguire
74 Trinity Place
New York 6, New York
My dear Mr. Maguire:
div1.p:
I am sorry indeed to hear that you have
had a condition that comes mostly to physicians.
Don't let it worry you too much as I have seen
many patients live a long, long time if they take
care of themselves.

I appreciate greatly the receipt of the
montages.

You say that you are planning to free-
lance magazine articles for a year or so.

This is the 50th anniversary of the
conquest of yellow fever by Walter Reed and his
colleagues. I have made that my hobby and a few
of us are hoping that a suitable article might be
prepared for some magazine. I spoke about this
to Steven Spencer of the Saturday Evening Post
but the Post has carried a somewhat similar
article a few years ago and was not in the mood
to do another one. I asked Bob Potter whether he
wanted to do it but haven't heard. If he doesn't
want to do it, would you be interested? I enclose
a little story on the subject. I wish I had time
to do it myself but I don't.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
